newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian police release detained Tibetan protesters.
newsitem.headline: Indian police release detained Tibetan protesters.

text.p: Indian police released 52 Tibetan exiles detained after a noisy protest outside Beijing's embassy in New Delhi, police officials said on Sunday.
Police said they were held for about four hours on Saturday before being released.
The demonstrators shouted slogans such as "China go out, free Tibet" and burnt the Chinese flag outside the embassy compound in the city's Chanakyapuri area, police said.
The demonstration was one of a series of protests by Tibetan exiles during a three-day state visit to India by Chinese President Jiang Zemin, the first by a Chinese head of state.
Witnesses said a Chinese official came out of the embassy compound and asked police to remove the demonstrators, who were later dragged into police buses and driven away.
Last Thursday, demonstrators in a New Delhi Tibetan encampment burnt an effigy of Jiang and the Chinese flag.
Around 130,000 Tibetans live in India, 4,000 of them in the Indian capital.
Many of them arrived with the Dalai Lama, the Himalayan region's spiritual leader, after an abortive 1959 uprising against China's annexation of Tibet.
The Buddhist spiritual leader has lived in exile in the north Indian Himalayan town of Dharamsala since then.
